unnormalised: So, someone asked if online learning is actually worth it in India? As someone who's spent more time staring at a laptop screen than at my chai lately, let me give you the *gyaan*.
normalised: So, someone asked if online learning is actually worth it in India? As someone who's spent more time staring at a laptop screen than at my chai lately, let me give you the *gyaan*.

unnormalised: First off, let's be real. Remember those days cramming for IIT-JEE and CAT exams with 200 other students in a classroom hotter than a tandoor? Yeah, online learning lets you avoid that. Plus, you can attend lectures in your pajamas! Try doing *that* at your local coaching center. I've attended lectures wearing a lungi more times than I care to admit (camera off, of course!).
normalised: First off, let's be real. Remember those days cramming for I-I-T-J-E-E and C-A-T exams with two hundred other students in a classroom hotter than a tandoor? Yeah, online learning lets you avoid that. Plus, you can attend lectures in your pajamas! Try doing *that* at your local coaching center. I've attended lectures wearing a lungi more times than I care to admit (camera off, of course!).

unnormalised: Now, the good stuff. EdTech companies are throwing courses at us like it's Diwali and they're handing out *mithai*. You can learn coding (Python, Java, you name it!), data science, even how to play the sitar online! Seriously, I saw a course for ₹499 the other day. Cheaper than a large pizza! (Although, TBH, I’d rather have the pizza).
normalised: Now, the good stuff. E-D-Tech companies are throwing courses at us like it's Diwali and they're handing out *mithai*. You can learn coding (Python, Java, you name it!), data science, even how to play the sitar online! Seriously, I saw a course for rupee four hundred and ninety nine the other day. Cheaper than a large pizza! (Although, T-B-H, I’d rather have the pizza).

unnormalised: But hold on, it’s not all rainbows and unicorns. Internet connectivity is still spotty in many parts of India. Imagine being in the middle of a crucial online class, and BAM! Power cut. That’s happened to me more times than I can count. My family now treats the "Internet's gone down!" cry like the dinner bell.
normalised: But hold on, it’s not all rainbows and unicorns. Internet connectivity is still spotty in many parts of India. Imagine being in the middle of a crucial online class, and B-A-M! Power cut. That’s happened to me more times than I can count. My family now treats the "Internet's gone down!" cry like the dinner bell.

unnormalised: And then there's the "focus" problem. It’s easy to get distracted. One minute you're learning about machine learning, the next you're watching cat videos on YouTube. Plus, your mom might interrupt with "Beta, chai pi lo!" every 15 minutes. It's a blessing and a curse, really.
normalised: And then there's the "focus" problem. It’s easy to get distracted. One minute you're learning about machine learning, the next you're watching cat videos on YouTube. Plus, your mom might interrupt with "Beta, chai pi lo!" every fifteen minutes. It's a blessing and a curse, really.

unnormalised: I mean, let's be honest. Can you really get the same networking opportunities as you would at, say, IIM Ahmedabad just by doing an online MBA? Probably not. Some things, like those awkward group projects and networking events, are just part of the traditional experience.
normalised: I mean, let's be honest. Can you really get the same networking opportunities as you would at, say, I-I-M Ahmedabad just by doing an online M-B-A? Probably not. Some things, like those awkward group projects and networking events, are just part of the traditional experience.

unnormalised: But look, online learning *is* convenient. It gives you access to courses you wouldn't have otherwise. You can learn at your own pace, rewind lectures (thank God!), and avoid traffic jams. The value prop is actually pretty good. It's also a great way to upskill. Companies are increasingly wanting things like AI/ML skillsets, and there's no better way than to take a class from, like, 10 PM to 1 AM.
normalised: But look, online learning *is* convenient. It gives you access to courses you wouldn't have otherwise. You can learn at your own pace, rewind lectures (thank God!), and avoid traffic jams. The value prop is actually pretty good. It's also a great way to upskill. Companies are increasingly wanting things like A-I slash M-L skillsets, and there's no better way than to take a class from, like, ten P-M to one A-M.

unnormalised: So, is it worth it? Depends on you, bhai. If you're disciplined, self-motivated, and have a decent internet connection, then absolutely! Just remember to wear pants during video calls (speaking from personal experience...). Also, keep an eye out for legit certifications; there are some dodgy providers out there. Check for things like ISO 9001 certifications, or better yet, make sure some Big 4 firms recognize the course/certification. And for goodness sakes, turn off notifications when you're attending class! You got this!
